page.title: A Smile as Big as the Moon

revision.text:
{{Infobox television | show_name = A Smile as Big as the Moon | image = File:A_Smile_as_Big_as_the_Moon_movie_poster.jpg | image_size = | image_alt = | caption = | genre = | creator = | based_on = | writer = Thomas Rickman | screenplay = | story = | director = [[James Steven Sadwith]] | starring = [[John Corbett (actor)|John Corbett]]
[[Jessy Schram]]
[[Cynthia Watros]]
[[Logan Huffman]]
[[Breezy Eslin]]
[[Peter ten Brink]]
[[David Lambert (actor)|David Lambert]]
[[Jimmy Bellinger]]
[[Tanner Dow]]
[[E. Roger Mitchell]]
[[Keith Flippen]]
[[Moira Kelly]]
[[Mike Pniewski]]
[[Louise Linton]] | narrated = | theme_music_composer = Mark Adler | country = [[United States]] | language = [[American English|English]] | num_episodes = | producer = Pat Chapman
Cameron Johann
Shawn McClaren
Dan Paulson
[[Brent Shields]] | editor = Michael D. Ornstein | cinematography = Roy H. Wagner | runtime = | company = [[Hallmark Hall of Fame]] | distributor = | budget = | network = [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] | first_aired = {{Film date|TV=y|2012|01|29}} | last_aired = | preceded_by = ''[[Have a Little Faith (film)|Have a Little Faith]]'' | followed_by = ''Firelight'' | website = }} '''''A Smile as Big as the Moon''''' is a [[Hallmark Hall of Fame]] television movie. The film debuted on [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] on January 29, 2012. [[John Corbett (actor)|John Corbett]] stars in this film based on the 2002 memoir of the same title by teacher Mike Kersjes and Joe Layden.{{cite web|url=http://lccn.loc.gov/2001048779 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120709192342/http://lccn.loc.gov/2001048779 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=July 9, 2012 |title=A Smile as Big as the Moon |publisher=Library of Congress |work=Library of Congress Online Catalog |accessdate=February 2, 2012 }} The movie shows the challenges Kersjes faced as he worked to bring out the best from his [[special education]] students by taking them to [[United States Space Camp|Space Camp]], which had, until that time been perceived as a program best suited to advanced science and math students, well beyond the reach of special education students. Several actors playing students in the film have [[Down syndrome]], [[autism]] and/or [[learning disability|learning disabilities]].{{cite web | url=http://gettingsmart.com/news/a-smile-as-big-as-the-moon-airs-abc-tonight-9-pm-est/ | title=‘A Smile As Big As the Moon’ Airs ABC January 29th | date=January 8, 2012 | accessdate=February 2, 2012 | author=Cargill, Sarah}} ==Plot== Ben, a student with Down syndrome, in Mike Kersjes's [[Forest Hills Northern High School]], [[Grand Rapids, Michigan]], special education class, dreams of becoming an [[astronaut]]. Kersjes, who is also a [[American football|football]] coach is inspired to pursue Space Camp for his students. Obstacles mount as school administrators object to the expense and Space Camp officials have no experience with special-ed students. Teacher Robynn McKinney supports Kersjes's efforts. Eventually the trip is approved by the necessary parties, and Kersjes faces another set of challenges: fundraising, preparing the students for their trip with science and physical education, and battling bullying and belittling from other students. Kersjes engages the football team in these endeavors. ==Filming== The film was shot primarily in [[Wilmington, North Carolina]] and at [[United States Space Camp]] in [[Huntsville, Alabama]].http://www.mlive.com/tv/index.ssf/2012/01/a_smile_as_big_as_the_moon_sta.html One scene used Sky Theater inside [[Ingram Planetarium]] of [[Sunset Beach, North Carolina]], which was adapted to appear as a [[planetarium]] would have in 1988. Filming took place there September 28, 2011.{{cite news|url=http://www.myrtlebeachonline.com/2012/01/22/2617313/nc-planetarium-has-starring-role.html |title=N.C. planetarium has starring role in upcoming TV movie |last=Palisin |first=Steve |work=[[The Sun News]] |date=2012-01-22 |accessdate=2012-01-25 }}{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} ==Cast== * [[John Corbett (actor)|John Corbett]] as Mike Kersjes: A high school special education teacher who takes his class to [[United States Space Camp|Space Camp]]{{cite web|url=http://www.reelz.com/movie/291082/a-smile-as-big-as-the-moon/cast |title=A Smile as Big as the MoonCast & Crew |publisher=Reelz.com |accessdate=February 2, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120202054223/http://www.reelz.com/movie/291082/a-smile-as-big-as-the-moon/cast/ |archivedate=February 2, 2012 }} * [[Jessy Schram]] as Robynn McKinney * [[Cynthia Watros]] as Dr. Deborah Barnhart * [[Logan Huffman]] as Scott Goudy: A boy with [[Dyslexia]] and [[anger management]] problems who hates being in special ed. * [[Breezy Eslin]] as Stephanie Reinks: A girl with [[Attention deficit disorder|ADD]] and [[Bipolar disorder]]. She is also never one to let anything slide. * [[Abigale Coorigan]] as Lisa Casey: A girl with [[Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder|ADHD]] and [[Obsessive compulsive disorder|OCD]]. She is also the class tattletale. * [[Peter ten Brink]] as Ben Schmidt: A boy with [[Down syndrome]]. * [[David Lambert (actor)|David Lambert]] as Steve Bennett: A boy with [[Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder|ADHD]] and [[Tourette syndrome]]. He is the most hyperactive student in the class. * [[Jimmy Bellinger]] as Matt Snyder: A boy with [[Autism]]. He is a whiz of [[mathematics]] and [[science]]. * Kesun Loder ([[K'Sun Ray]]) as Lewis Dayhuff: A boy with [[Dyslexia]]. He lives with his 13th foster family, and also had a temper that made Scott seem tame. * [[Tyrin Niles Wyche]] as Jamal Davis: A boy who is mentally slow and slow to get agitated. He is the most quiet student. * [[Tanner Dow]] as Adam Plowright: A boy with [[Autism]] and [[Obsessive compulsive disorder|OCD]]. He is the class gentle giant with a "heart that matches his size". * [[E. Roger Mitchell]] as Tom Keller: The principal at Forest Hills Northern High School. * [[Keith Flippen]] as Dennis Schmidt: The father of Ben Schmidt. * [[Moira Kelly]] as Darcy Kersjes: The wife of Mike Kersjes. * [[Mike Pniewski]] as Big Dan: The owner of a fast food restaurant called Big Dan's Burger Shed. * [[Louise Linton]] as Julie: The counselor for the team "Big Dan's Burger Shed". * [[Fred Griffith (actor)|Fred Griffith]] as Judge{{cite web | url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2100380/fullcredits#cast | title=Full Cast and Crew for A Smile as Big as the Moon | publisher=IMDB | accessdate=February 2, 2012}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{IMDb title|id=2100380}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Smile As Big As the Moon}} [[Category:2012 television films]] [[Category:Hallmark Hall of Fame episodes]] [[Category:Films shot at the U.S. Space & Rocket Center]] [[Category:Films shot in North Carolina]] [[Category:Films shot in Alabama]] [[Category:Space Camp]] [[Category:Special education]]

revision.comment: add JSTOR; add indexing info; more independent sources would be nice, but there are now 3rd party sources showing (very moderate) notability (because in MLA database)
revision.text:
{{Infobox journal | title = African Music | image = African_Music_(journal)_cover_image.jpg | former_name = | abbreviation = Afr. Music | discipline = [[Ethnomusicology]] | editors = Lee Watkins | publisher = [[International Library of African Music]] | country = | history = 1954-current | frequency = Annual | openaccess = [[Delayed open access journal|Delayed]], two-years | license = | impact = | impact-year = | ISSN = 0065-4019 | eISSN = 2524-2741 | CODEN = | JSTOR = 00654019 | LCCN = 60045755 | OCLC = 1036109 | website = http://journal.ru.ac.za/index.php/africanmusic/index | link1 = http://journal.ru.ac.za/index.php/africanmusic/issue/current | link1-name = Online access | link2 = http://journal.ru.ac.za/index.php/africanmusic/issue/archive | link2-name = Online archive }} '''''African Music''''' is an annual [[peer-reviewed]]ed [[academic journal]] published by the [[International Library of African Music]]. It covers contextualized studies of [[Music of Africa|African music]] and related arts. Articles are made freely accessible after a two-year embargo period.<ref>{{cite news |last1=South African Cultural Observatory |title=ILAM offers open access to African Music Journal |url=https://www.southafricanculturalobservatory.org.za/article/ilam-offers-open-access-to-african-music-journal |accessdate=28 November 2018 |publisher=South African Cultural Observatory |date=28 March 2017}}</ref>
==History== The journal was established by [[Hugh Tracey]] in 1954,<ref>{{cite web |last1=Open Music Library |title=Journals: African Music |url=https://openmusiclibrary.org/journal/african-music/ |website=Openmusiclibrary |publisher=Alexander Street |accessdate=28 November 2018}}</ref> in the same year as the [[International Library of African Music]]. Tracey was the first [[editor-in-chief]] until his death in 1977.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Thram |first1=Diane |title=From the editor |journal=African Music: Journal of the International Library of African Music |date=2007 |volume=8 |issue=1 |page=4–5 |doi=10.21504/amj.v8i1.1708}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=History: Hugh Tracey founds the Int'l Library of African Music (ILAM) |url=https://www.kalimbamagic.com/info/history/22-hugh-tracey-founds-the-int-l-library-of-african-music-ilam |publisher=Kalimba Magic |accessdate=28 November 2018}}</ref> Publication was interrupted from 2000 until 2007. Since it was re-launched in 2007, the journal includes a collection of music performances and audio examples relating to articles published within the respective issues.<ref>{{cite web |title=About the journal |website=International Library of African Music |url=http://journal.ru.ac.za/index.php/africanmusic/about |publisher=[[Rhodes University]] |accessdate=19 July 2018}}</ref>
===Editors-in-chief=== The following persons are or have been editor-in-chief of the journal: *1954–1977: [[Hugh Tracey]] *1977–1999: [[Andrew Tracey]] *2007–2016: Diane Thram *2017–current: Lee Watkins
==Abstracting and indexing== The journal is abstracted and indexed in:<ref>{{MIAR|0065-4019}}</ref> *[[Academic Search Premier]] *[[International Bibliography of the Social Sciences]] *[[Modern Language Association Database]] *[[Music Index]] *[[Répertoire International de Littérature Musicale]]
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== *{{Official website|http://journal.ru.ac.za/index.php/africanmusic/index}}
[[Category:Ethnomusicology]] [[Category:Music journals]] [[Category:Academic journals published in South Africa]] [[Category:English-language journals]] [[Category:Annual journals]] [[Category:Arts journals]] [[Category:Delayed open access journals]]
